bib.title: Measurement of Neutron Reaction Cross Sections inCarbon using a Single Crystal Diamond Detector.

free_txt: A.Krasa, A.J.M.Plompen, P.Schillebeeckx,
M.L.Sergi.
Associazione EURATOM-ENEA Sulla Fusione,
ENEA C.R.Frascati,via E.Fermi,45,00044 Frascati, Rome,
Italy.   M.Pillon, M.Angelone.
Tabulated data are given.
"Experimental response functions of a single-crystal
diamond detector for 5-20.5 MeV neutrons."
Preliminary publication.
M.M.
Request of data sent 08-08-2011 to Mario Pillon
mario.pillon@enea.it .
Data were received 01-09-2011 from Mario
Pillon.
SD: Type of DETECTOR deleted.
Total energies of the produced charged particles
versus mean neutron energy were calculated, are given
in Table 1 of S,AIP-1412,121,2011.
For background and possible interfering peaks.
Diamond detector used was produced by Diamond
Detector Ltd (UK). It consists of a high purity single
crystal detector packed in Al housing with a male SMA
connector. The SCD is mounted over a 8mm hole on a
Rogers 4003 PCB substrate.The detector is a single
crystal of 4.7x4.7x0.5 mm**3 and a nitrogen impurities
level smaller than 5ppb. The electrical contacts are
4.5 mm in diameter and are made with a metallization,
top and bottom, of diamond like carbon (DLC)/Pt/Au
layers.
The SCD detector was located at different angles with
respect to the deuteron beam at 8cm distance from the
center of the target.
To determine the energy linearity and resolution of the
detector its response for charged particles produced in
the C-12(n,a)Be-9 reaction was studied.
Experimental measured efficiency was 1.9E-4 counts/cm2
at 8.3 MeV neutron energy (maximum measured value) and
2.5E-5 counts/cm2 at 19 MeV neutron energy (minimum
measured value).
Measurements lasted typically 30 min and after each run
the high voltage was switched off and on - to avoid the
polarization effects.
Intrinsic energy resolution about 56 keV (FWHM).
The proton recoil telescope was positioned at
an angle of 21 deg. and 40cm from the target center.
For neutron flux measurement.
Deuteron beams on deuterium gas and solid
tritium targets .
The D2 gas-target had a gas pressure of 100 kPa, a gas
cell length of 40 mm, a Mo entrance foil thickness of
5 um and a 1 mm Ta beam stop. The T/Ti-target had a
Ti thickness of 2.245 mg/cm2 (5% uncertainty), a
nominal T/Ti ratio of 1.4 and a gold backing of 0.5 mm
thickness.
Neutron fluence was measured by Nb foils using the
Nb-93(n,2n)Nb-92 activation reaction (En >14 MeV) or
by a proton recoil detector (En<9MeV). Nb foils of
2.0 cm diameter and 0.5cm thick were irradiated at a
fixed angle of 60 deg. and 8cm from the target center.
The measured neutron fluence in the reference position
was rescaled to the actual fluence at the position of
the SCD detector using the EnergySet program:
Ed Target type Emission Angle  Emean   Emin    Emax
MeV            degrees         MeV     MeV     MeV
Neutron energies were determined from a calibration
averaging over several beam conditions and detector
angles using the peak position of the 12C(n,a0)9Be reac
Several reactions occurring in carbon were
identified in the collected PHS.
Pulse height analysis method (PHA).
Proton recoil to neutron flux measurement for
En < 9 MeV.
Activation analysis for neutron flux
measurement En > 12 MeV.
, also NNEANDC-311 "U".
For neutron fluence
determination by solid Ti/T target. For En>12 MeV.
For neutron fluence
determination by gas target. for En <9 MeV.
Alpha triple isotope source of Pu-239, Am-241, Cm-244
were used for energy calibration (5.16,5.48, 5.90 MeV).
Q-values.
Data are final, confirmed and approved by
Mario Pillon 11-10-2011.
The net peak area corresponding to C-12(n,a0)Be-9 peak,
deduced from the measured PHS spectra normalized to the
product of the neutron fluence and detector area,
should be directly proportional to the cross-section.
Uncertainty of counting statistics in the
net peak area.
Uncertainty in the target thickness (stated to
be 5% by the manufacturer)
Error of fluence determination
above 12 MeV between 4.2 % and 6.3 % ; includes:
statistic of the 934 keV gamma-ray peak of Nb-92m, the
HPGe detector efficiency calibration, Nb-93(n,2n)Nb-92m
reaction cross-section and the Nb-monitor position.
In the case of gas target - this uncertainty is a
combination of the counting statistics, the standard
deviation of the number of counts acquired for monitor
normalization,the hydrogen content of the radiator,
the total and angular H(n,p)n cross-sections, and the
uncertainty of the telescope position and internal
geometry (distance between radiator and Si-detector
aperture,the radii of the radiator and Si-detector
aperture, influence of scattering in the proportional
wires and apertures).
Total error is 3.4% at 7.3 MeV,
3.9% at 7.8 MeV and 10% at 8.3 MeV neutron energy.
As sample - a diamond detector was used .
The active volume was 8.0 mm3.
Data are on Fig.7 of J,NIM/A,640,185,2011.
